channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Tells Nation There Is Hope After a Devastating Year
item.description: In his first prime-time address from the White House, the president said that he would order states to make all adults eligible for the vaccine by May 1 and that a return to normalcy was possible by July 4.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden, addressing the nation from the White House on Thursday, did not mention his predecessor, Donald J. Trump, but his speech drew sharp contrasts to him.

item.title: In Nevada, Unemployed Workers Wait for Aid That Will Still Not Be Enough
item.description: Stimulus checks may be on their way, but those struggling to get by worry that the money will soon be gone. “Every morning I wake up thinking about where my help is going to come from,” one woman said.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guadalupe Rodriguez, left, moved in with Bobby Hernandez, a co-worker who was laid off, and another roommate late last year. The three are still struggling to pay bills.

item.title: The Lessons of One of the Worst Years in American Life
item.description: President Donald J. Trump lost his job in large part for mishandling a crisis he at first denied. President Biden knows his legacy depends on bringing the catastrophe to a swift conclusion.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden signing the $1.9 trillion stimulus package in the Oval Office on Thursday.

item.title: The Fight Is On to Define the Pandemic Aid Bill
item.description: Democrats have embraced the scope and cost of the stimulus measure, daring Republicans to campaign against the myriad benefits it delivers for their constituents.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday. The bill is likely to be a main point of contention in next year’s midterm elections, as Democrats seek to retain their thin majorities in the House and the Senate.

item.title: Which Families Will Receive the Most Money From the Stimulus Bill?
item.description: A large child tax credit will benefit the lowest-income families in particular.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Parlapiano and Josh Katz

item.title: Need Health Insurance? A Guide to New Options Under the Stimulus.
item.description: There is more financial assistance for more people seeking coverage. And many people who are already covered can get discounts, too, if they sign up.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Cyrus Vance Will Not Run Again for Manhattan D.A.
item.description: The decision by Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the district attorney since 2010, sets off a scramble for the office and makes it likely a new prosecutor will inherit an investigation into the former president’s business.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., who has been Manhattan district attorney since 2010, has told his staff he will not stand for re-election.

item.title: Cuomo Faces New Threat: Impeachment Inquiry Led by Democrats
item.description: The move by the State Assembly sets the stage for what could be the state’s first impeachment effort in more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní, J. David Goodman and Jesse McKinley
item.media:description: State lawmakers suggest that Gov. Andrew Cuomo has “lost the confidence of the public and the State Legislature.”

item.title: U.S. Keeps Vaccine Stockpile as Other Countries Struggle
item.description: The U.S. hasn’t authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine yet, so doses sit idly as other countries beg for access. Here’s the latest on the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Faulty Software Snarls Vaccine Sign-Ups
item.description: Health departments continue to grapple with delays caused by technical problems with numerous websites used for making appointments.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times
item.media:description: Awaiting shots in Richmond, Va. Health departments around the country continue to face delays giving vaccines, in part because of flawed appointment software like that used in Richmond.

item.title: Vaccines Are Here. So Is Reckless Behavior.
item.description: There are so many reasons to feel hopeful, and yet so many reasons to still hold firmly to anxiety. As mask fatigue sets in and more arms get jabbed, it’s easy to forget that plenty of New Yorkers are still vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nasim Almuntaser outside the bodega he works at in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, where mask fatigue set in months ago.

item.title: 30 percent of the country, including 41 percent of Republicans, doesn’t want the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Yazidi Women Once Enslaved by ISIS Are Reunited With Their Children
item.description: Yazidi women freed from sexual slavery under ISIS were forced to give up their babies. Two years later, some are risking everything to get them back.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yazidi women waited on the Iraqi side of the border last week, hoping to reunite with children in Syria whom they hadn’t seen in years.

item.title: How Your 2020 Taxes Are Affected by the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: New rules for a new reality, from stimulus payments to retirement withdrawals to unemployment insurance, could cut your bill or even generate extra refunds.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: A Love Letter to My Accountant
item.description: My relationship with him is the most positive one I’ve ever had with a man over money.
item.dc:creator: Kaitlyn Greenidge

item.title: A Break for Working Families
item.description: The government is allowing people who qualify for the earned-income tax credit to use income from either 2020 or 2019, whichever will result in a bigger credit.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Hope as a Public Health Tool
item.description: President Biden, speaking from the White House, reached for a little optimism.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A child attending online classes in Los Angeles.

item.title: Democrats Split From Cuomo as Impeachment Inquiry Looms
item.description: State lawmakers took the first step toward possibly impeaching Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as investigations into his conduct unfold.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: Odessa
item.description: A struggling school system. An oil bust. A marching band determined to keep playing through a pandemic. This is the story of one Texas high school in crisis — and trying to reopen its doors.
item.dc:creator: Annie Brown, Sindhu Gnanasambandan, Soraya Shockley, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Tobin, Tamir Kalifa and Lauren Jackson

item.title: Spike Lee Predicts the Future
item.description: The director of “Da 5 Bloods” talks about why his old movies still resonate, whether an awards snub even matters and how it’s not his job to end racism.
item.dc:creator: Kara Swisher
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Elias Williams for The New York Times

item.title: Still Processing Returns for a New Season: Subscribe Now
item.description: The culture writers Jenna Wortham and Wesley Morris are back for another season — and no topic is off limits.

item.title: What to Know Now About the Newsom Recall Effort
item.description: Friday: Have questions about the effort to oust Gov. Gavin Newsom from office? Here are the answers.
item.dc:creator: Priya Arora and Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom delivered his State of the State address at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, saying, “We will not be distracted from getting shots in arms and our economy booming again.”

item.title: Joe Biden Knew He Was Onto Something Long Before We Did
item.description: The advent of Covid-19 changed his conception of the presidency for the better.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Taylor Swift Is Bringing Us Back to Nature
item.description: Her work is overflowing with the language and landscapes of the natural world. As a father and a conservation scientist, I value that.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Opperman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Arsh Raziuddin/The New York Times, via Photos by by David Crotty, via Patrick McMullan, via Getty Images

item.title: The Case for Covid Optimism
item.description: Why Dr. Ashish Jha thinks life could return to normal very soon.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph, via Brown University

item.title: What Happened When Germany’s Far-Right Party Railed Against Lockdowns
item.description: It didn’t work.
item.dc:creator: Anna Sauerbrey
item.media:description: A protester against lockdown measures in Berlin last year. Alternative for Germany has sought to improve its electoral standing by embracing anti-lockdown radicalism.

item.title: Joe Biden Is a Transformational President
item.description: We’re seeing a policy realignment without a partisan realignment.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post, via Getty Images

item.title: Ending the End of Welfare as We Knew It
item.description: The Democrats’ new child benefit is a very big deal.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.category: Aid to Families With Dependent Children

item.title: Covid Vaccines Aren't Enough. We Need More Coronavirus Tests.
item.description: Even with vaccines, the coronavirus won’t subside if we can’t keep tabs on it.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer B. Nuzzo and Emily N. Pond

item.title: Trump Health Care Policies That Biden Should Consider Keeping
item.description: Biden may want to continue the previous administration’s efforts to lower drug prices and make medical costs transparent.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Rosenthal
item.media:description: President Donald Trump meeting with health care executives in 2017. Some of his proposals dismayed the health care industry.

item.title: The Year Grandparents Lost
item.description: The enforced separations of the pandemic have brought a particular kind of mourning to many grandparents.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Cydni Elledge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kathy Koehler of Ann Arbor, Mich., relies on Skype calls to connect with her infant grandson, Elya, who lives in London. He was born at the start of the pandemic and they have not yet been able to meet in person.

item.title: In Lady Bird Johnson’s Secret Diaries, a Despairing President and a Crucial Spouse
item.description: A new book reveals how the former first lady not only provided a spouse’s emotional ballast but also served as an unrivaled counselor who helped persuade Lyndon B. Johnson to stay in office.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Lady Bird Johnson: Hiding in Plain Sight (Book)
item.media:description: Lady Bird Johnson in 1961. The first lady kept a diary, but she ordered that a part of it be kept secret for years after her death.

item.title: Why I Took a Vow of Celibacy
item.description: In my life, sex and love have been twisted up with childhood trauma. Time for a break.
item.dc:creator: Paula McLain

item.title: L.A.P.D. Strongly Criticized Over Handling of George Floyd Protests
item.description: An independent report commissioned by the Los Angeles City Council faulted the department for its lack of planning and chaotic response.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, John Eligon and Will Wright
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers blocked the 110 freeway in Los Angeles last May during protests following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Biden Condemns Hate Crimes Against Asian-Americans
item.description: “It’s wrong,” President Biden said. “It’s un-American, and it must stop.”
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: A rally in February to oppose the series of hate crimes that have targeted Asian-American people in San Francisco.

item.title: What Are NFTs, Anyway? One Just Sold for $69 Million.
item.description: “Nonfungible tokens” and blockchain technology are taking the mainstream art world by storm, fetching huge prices. We explain, or try to.
item.dc:creator: Josie Thaddeus-Johns

item.title: Congress Closes Loophole That Made Veterans a Target of For-Profit Schools
item.description: The new economic stimulus package makes a tiny change that military veterans pushed for in hopes of stemming aggressive recruiting tactics.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: “They heard our voices, for once, and they righted the wrong,” said Tasha Berkhalter, an Army veteran who met with lawmakers last year.

item.title: Christopher Lovrien Is Charged With Two Murders Committed Two Decades Apart
item.description: Genetic genealogy connected Christopher Lovrien to a 1999 homicide victim, according to the authorities, who said they found the remains of a 2020 homicide victim when they searched his property.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Dave Killen/The Oregonian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Christopher Lovrien pleaded not guilty on Thursday in Portland, Ore., to two killings that took place more than two decades apart.

item.title: Will Newbies Keep Playing Tennis and Golf Now That Other Sports Are Back?
item.description: Recreational athletes flocked to accessible and safely distanced sports. Leaders in golf and tennis — both of which have had massive public investment — want to sustain their pandemic booms.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman and Bill Pennington
item.media:credit: Dylan Hollingsworth for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of women played a doubles match in January at Querbes Tennis Center in Shreveport, La. Chris Dudley, who operates the facility with his wife, Amy, said the growth there has been “quick and organic” since reopening full-time.

item.title: China's Dr. Fauci Urges Restraint in Fighting Covid-19
item.description: Zhang Wenhong has drawn a huge public following with a human touch and candid advice that sometimes runs counter to the government’s authoritarian instincts.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Wu Jun/Visual China Group via Getty Images
item.media:description: Zhang Wenhong, the top expert in Shanghai during the pandemic, won’t challenge the government but doesn’t always toe its line.

item.title: Meghan Highlights Depression in Pregnancy, an Overlooked Danger
item.description: A wave of responses from women who have experienced depression and suicidal thoughts is shedding light on the stark differences between how pregnancy is perceived and lived.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Meghan and Harry in 2019.

item.title: Aaron Rose, Photographer Whose Work Long Went Unseen, Dies at 84
item.description: Spurning commercialism, he made thousands of one-of-a-kind prints that for decades he largely kept to himself. Then came a show at the Whitney.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.category: Museum of the City of New York
item.media:description: Aaron Rose in his SoHo studio in 1997. He was an innovative and prolific photographer, making tens of thousands of one-of-a-kind images, but they were not exhibited for decades.

item.title: 13 Spring Recipes to Add to Your Cooking List
item.description: Celebrate the season’s arrival with dishes that make the most of its best and brightest produce.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky
item.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: The Runners High: How Exercise Affects Our Minds
item.description: For years we’ve been crediting endorphins, but it’s really about the endocannabinoids.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times

item.title: Essential Oils May Be Wreaking Havoc on Your Skin
item.description: When it comes to clean beauty, “natural” isn’t always best. Here’s what’s safe and beneficial, and what’s best to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Schiffer

item.title: ‘How Beautiful We Were,’ by Imbolo Mbue: An Excerpt
item.description: An excerpt from “How Beautiful We Were,” by Imbolo Mbue

item.title: Garrett Bradley Reminds Us That Black Joy Always Existed
item.description: Her elaborate video installation, which restages quiet and remarkable moments in early 20th-century Black life, is at the Museum of Modern Art.
item.dc:creator: Roberta Smith

item.title: A Postwar Mercedes, Still Overshadowed by Its Racing Cousins
item.description: The Adenauer Benz helped lift the automaker after its work for the Nazis. Today, pristine models go for a small fraction of Gullwings from the same era.
item.dc:creator: Brett Berk
item.media:description: A Mercedes-Benz 300d from 1960 at a 2018 car show in Basel, Switzerland.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Reminisces About One Year of ‘Living Contagiously’
item.description: “If somebody said ‘N95’ to you one year ago, you’d think they were a bingo caller,” Kimmel joked on America’s “coronaversary.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Some LGBTQ People Are Saying 'No Thanks' to the Covid Vaccine
item.description: Evidence suggests that some sexual and gender minorities — especially people of color — are hesitant to be vaccinated because of mistrust of the medical establishment.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Bronze Age Tomb in Spain Hints Women Helped Govern
item.description: A tomb unearthed in Spain has prompted archaeologists to reconsider assumptions about women’s power in Bronze Age European societies.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Pinkowski

item.title: Photos of Snowflakes Like You've Never Seen Them Before
item.description: Whether made with setups using sapphire and carbon fiber or an old mitten and a standard camera, these photographic approaches allow close-ups of the tiny masterpieces formed when snow falls.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: The Virus Spread Where Restaurants Reopened or Mask Mandates Were Absent
item.description: C.D.C. researchers found that coronavirus infections and death rates rose in U.S. counties permitting in-person dining or not requiring masks.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: “You have decreases in cases and deaths when you wear masks, and you have increases in cases and deaths when you have in-person restaurant dining,” Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, said Friday.

item.title: Neanderthals Listened to the World Much Like Us
item.description: A reconstructed Neanderthal ear adds a new piece to the puzzle of whether the early humans could speak.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: The Natural History Museum, London/Science Source
item.media:description: To begin to figure out whether Neanderthals could talk, researchers studied fossilized ear bones, to reconstruct how and what our early ancestors heard.

item.title: Hilaria Baldwin and the Strange Allure of Celebrity Fertility
item.description: Why we can’t stop talking about her … whole thing.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alec and Hilaria Baldwin at the American Ballet Theater spring gala in May 2019.

item.title: It May Be Time to Start Worrying About the Estate Tax
item.description: Most people have been able to pass on assets like a family home without federal tax, but that could be changing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sullivan

item.title: Covering the Royal Family: Reporter Discusses the Challenges
item.description: The Times’s London bureau chief talks about the challenges of reporting on Buckingham Palace and the fallout of Oprah Winfrey’s interview with Harry and Meghan.
item.dc:creator: Katie Van Syckle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Phil Harris/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: The British royal family at Westminster Abbey in London last year. Understanding the inner workings of the monarchy poses a constant challenge to reporters.

item.title: Covid-19 Vaccines: Dr. B Website Will Match You With Leftover Doses
item.description: More than half a million people have signed up for Dr. B, a service that promises to match them with clinics struggling to equitably dole out extra doses before they expire.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allison Ingram, a pharmacist, administered the Moderna Covid vaccine to Thomas Black at Cornerstone Pharmacy - Rodney Parham in Little Rock, Ark., on Monday.

item.title: Meghan and Harry's Interview Shows the Monarchy Must Go
item.description: Any nation that still has a monarchy in 2021 is proving itself to have a mortifying lack of revolutionary gumption.
item.dc:creator: Hamilton Nolan
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s Queen Elizabeth in the 2019 Trooping the Colour parade.

item.title: Is a Long-Dismissed Forgery Actually the Oldest Known Biblical Manuscript?
item.description: In 1883, a manuscript found near the Dead Sea caused an international sensation. It was denounced as a fake, and soon vanished. But what if it was the only known source text for the Hebrew Bible?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Illustrated by London News Group/ The British Library Board
item.media:description: Shapira’s discovery was covered extensively in magazines like The Graphic, which ran these drawings showing details of the manuscript, other examples of ancient Hebrew script and the area near the Dead Sea where the fragments were found.

item.title: The Best Bagels Are in California (Sorry, New York)
item.description: West Coast bakers are driving a great bagel boom, producing some of the most delicious versions around and finding ways to expand during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Preston Gannaway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emily Winston opened Boichik Bagels just a few months before the pandemic hit Berkeley, and quickly reoriented her business to takeout and delivery.

item.title: Spelling Bee
item.description: Use 7 letters to make as many words as you can.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, Tiles and More
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Vertex.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Vertex
item.description: Connect the dots to reveal the hidden picture.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Tiles
item.description: Our soothing matching game may help you de-stress.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
